snippet: Automakers embraced Takata’s cheaper technology almost 20 years ago despite signs that it was unsafe. The airbags are now at the center of the auto industry’s biggest recall....
abstract: Newly reported details of decision-making by carmakers, including General Motors, show companies traded off safety issues on Takata airbags almost 20 years ago, in attempt to save several dollars per airbag; automakers also pressured their suppliers to make cost paramount; at least 14 people have been killed by faulty Takata airbag inflaters.
lead_paragraph: Automakers embraced Takata’s cheaper technology almost 20 years ago despite signs that it was unsafe. The airbags are now at the center of the auto industry’s biggest recall.

headline.main: A Cheaper Airbag, and Takata’s Road to a Deadly Crisis
headline.print_headline: The Quest to Save a Few Dollars  Per Airbag Led to a Deadly Crisis
